60 MPH.

SCHOOL BUSSES

When approaching a school bus from either direction, which has
stopped to receive or discharge any passengers, driver must stop
and not proceed until school bus resumes motion. Motorist need
not stop if the bus is on the opposite lane of a dual highway or
within the limits of any incorporated city or town with a population
in excess of 100,000, according to the most recent Federal decennial
census.

STOPPING ON HIGHWAYS

When stopping for any purpose, park off the traveled portion of the
highway outside the line of traffic. If your vehicle is disabled, raising
the hood or tying a handkerchief to the door handle or radio
antenna will help call attention to your predicament.

PASSING ZONE

As you drive, observe the center lines on the roadway. Keep in the
right-hand lane and do not pass the car ahead when the solid line
Is on your side of the road. Posted speed signs, warning and
directional signs are placed along the highway for your guidance
and protection. When approaching a vehicle from the front, head-

The Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Park

23 SHRIVER HOMESTEAD & MILL, a museum demonstrating 150 years
of American country life, Union Mills on U.S. 140.

24 WESTMINSTER, site of a restored 150-year-old farm, now the
CARROLL COUNTY FARM MUSEUM and nearby HISTORICAL HOUSE
MUSEUM, featuring a rare collection of antique fashion model dolls,
Zuber wallpaper, and an exhibit of the first county-wide RFD in the U.S.,
on U.S. 140.

25 INTERNATIONAL GIFT SHOP OF THE CHURCH WORLD SERVICE
MISSION, sells unusual items from around the world to support its
activities, New Windsor.

26 WHITE'S FERRY, only surviving Potomac River Ferry, near WHITE’S
FERRY AQUA CLUB, a commercially operated recreational and campsite
area along the C & O CANAL, on Md. 107, 30 miles northwest of Wash-
ington, D. C. and near THE ARABIAN HORSE FARM at Barnesville.

Maryland’s historic gristmills. U.S. 1, to Kingsville then east on Jericho
Road.

35 ARMY ORDNANCE MUSEUM, Aberdeen Proving Grounds, present-
ing the world’s largest collection of mobile and armored war weapons,
indoor display temporarily closed, off U.S. 40.

36 coNowiInGOo DAM, controlling the Susquehanna River, provides

fine fishing in either the lake; or.the river below the dam, on U.S. 1.

37 BALTIMORE attractions are FORT McHENRY NATIONAL SHRINE,
where the Star-Spangled Banner flew and inspired Francis Scott Key to
compose our national anthem, the FLAG HOUSE MUSEUM, the SHOT
TOWER, the CHARLES CARROLL of CARROLLTON HOUSE, BABE
RUTH HOUSE, BALTIMORE AND OHIO TRANSPORTATION MUSEUM,
the PEALE MUSEUM (America’s first museum), the BALTIMORE MU-
SEUM OF ART, the WALTERS ART GALLERY, JOHNS HOPKINS HOS-
PITAL and UNIVERSITY, the PEABODY INSTITUTE, the EDGAR ALLAN
POE HOUSE, MOUNT CLAIRE MANSION, the ENOCH PRATT FREE
LIBRARY. At the MARYLAND HISTORICAL SOCIETY is the original
manuscript of the ““Star-Spangled Banner,” as well as a vast collection
of Maryland memorabilia, including many War of 1812 and Civil War
relics.

In Baltimore’s immense port area, at Pier 1, Pratt Street, in the heart of
downtown, lies the oldest ship of the United States Navy, the FRIGATE
CONSTELLATION, built in 1797 — now a Registered National Historic

FAIRHILL STEEPLECHASE and flat
turf racing, horse and cattle shows,
spring and fall, on Md. 273 and 280.

61 CHESAPEAKE & DELAWARE

CANAL, Chesapeake City, links Port

of Baltimore with Philadelphia and :
North Atlantic, site of Pump House and Water Wheel (1851). Registered
National Historic Landmark. U.S. 213.

62 OLD BOHEMIA CHURCH, Warwick: the site of the first Catholic
school in the British colonies, on Md. 282, off U.S. 213.

63 FREDERICKTOWN, a picturesque, waterside village with an old
grain warehouse of by-gone days converted into a restaurant near
GEORGETOWN, site of the KITTY KNIGHT HOUSE, now an inn named for
Mistress Kitty, who matched wits with a British admiral and saved the
town in the War of 1812, on U.S. 213.

64 CHESTERTOWN, an old beautiful waterfront community, the site
of Washington College (1782), the only college to which George Wash-
ington personally gave the right to use his name, on U.S. 213.

65 CENTREVILLE, an 18t
century town, with its old
Court House and Lawyer’s



dustry in continuous op-
eration, on Md. 318, near
Preston.

71 oLD TRINITY CHURCH, the oldest Protestant church (1674) in use
in the country, on Md. 16, 5 miles south of Cambridge.

72 BLACKWATER NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, the fall and winter
habitat of one of the nation’s largest concentrations of waterfowl, off Md.
335, 9 miles south of Cambridge. Open daily dawn ’til dusk. Visitor cen-
ter, picnic area, wildlife drive and observation tower.

73 MASON-DIXON MARKER, one of the boundary stones, set 200
years ago by the famous surveyors, Mason and Dixon, to divide Mary-
land from Pennsylvania and Delaware, which established the traditional
line between the North and the South, off U.S. 50 on Md. 467.

74 SALISBURY, the Eastern Shore’s major commercial center, the site
of the NATIONAL INDOOR OPEN TENMIS CHAMPIONSHIP TOURNA-
MENT, on U.S. 50 and 13.

75 OCEAN CITY, one of the finest resorts on the Atlantic Coast, on
ten miles of wide, white sandy beach, with a three-mile boardwalk, all
facilities. and accommodations, and nearby OCEAN DOWNS Harness
Track and FRONTIER TOWN for children. Marlin fishing, off Ocean City
is unexcelled.

Discover America



lights should be dimmed within 500 feet of the oncoming vehicle,
and when following another vehicle, headlights should be dimmed
within 200 feet to the rear of the vehicle being followed.

Landmark. Also in the port area is McCORMICK COMPANY, world’s

! Row still in use, and
largest spice processor, open for plant tours.

WRIGHT'S CHANCE, an ex-
cellent example of a colonial
Eastern Shore plantation
home, now a museum.

66 wye miLLs, an 18th
century country village with
an old school house, church,
and Maryland’s official tree,
THE WYE OAK (a white
oak), 450 years old, on Md.
404 off U.S. 50.

67 CHESAPEAKE BAY
MARITIME MUSEUM, St.
Michael’s, presents an array
of Bay relics and memora-
bilia, including several old
sailing craft, a lighthouse
and lightship, on Md. 33 off
U.S. 50. (Closed Monday)

68 EASTON, a charming
18th century town, once the
capital of the Eastern Shore,
site of the THIRD HAVEN

76 ASSATEAGUE ISLAND, wildly beautiful barrier reef, the home of
the famous CHINCOTEAGUE ponies, the site of national and state parks
developed for campers, sport fishermen and nature lovers.

77 SNOW HILL, the site of the NASSAWANGO IRON FURNACE ruins,
and the JULIA PURNELL MUSEUM with its unusual collection of historic
memorabilia, on U.S. 113.

78 PRINCESS ANNE, an 18th century town retaining much of its
original charm where in mid-October, “Olde Princess Anne Days” festival
is centered at the TEACKLE MANSION, on U.S. 13.

79 DEAL ISLAND, typical of many Chesapeake Bay fishing villages, on
Md. 363, off U.S. 13.

80 CRISFIELD, a leading Eastern Shore seafood center, port for the
Smith Island excursion boats, on Md. 413, off U.S. 13.

81 SMITH ISLAND, ten miles off shore, in Tangier Sound, a fishing
village virtually unchanged since its settling 300 years ago. Visited by
excursion boats from Crisfield in spring and summer.

82 REHOBETH PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH, the first Presbyterian
church in America (1705), on Md. 667, off U.S. 13.

83 POCOMOKE CITY, on the tropical-like Pocomoke River, noted for
its annual NATIONAL BASS ROUND-UP, on U.S. 13. :

Maryland law requires the operator of a vehicle involved in an
accident to stop immediately and remain at the scene of the accident
until the following requirements have been fulfilled:

1) Render assistance to any person injured.

2) Give his name, address and registration number of the vehicle
he is driving and shall upon request exhibit his operator’s or
chauffeur’s license to the person struck or the person attending
any vehicles involved in the collision.

REPORTING ACCIDENTS

The operator of every motor vehicle which is in any manner involved
In an accident within the state in which any person is killed or
injured, or in which damage to the property of any person including
himself, in excess of $100.00 is sustained, shall within 15 days re-
port the matter in writing to the DEPARTMENT OF MOTOR VEHICLES,
6601 RITCHIE HIGHWAY, N.E, GLEN BURNIE, MARYLAND 21061
Accident report forms may be obtained from the Department of
Motor Vehicles, State and Local Police Department.

of American country life, Union Mills on U.S. 140.

24 WESTMINSTER, site of a restored 150-year-old farm, now the
CARROLL COUNTY FARM MUSEUM and nearby HISTORICAL HOUSE
MUSEUM, featuring a rare collection of antique fashion model dolls,
Zuber wallpaper, and an exhibit of the first county-wide RFD in the U.S.,
on U.S. 140.

25 INTERNATIONAL GIFT SHOP OF THE CHURCH WORLD SERVICE
MISSION, sells unusual items from around the world to support its
activities, New Windsor.

26 WHITE'S FERRY, only surviving Potomac River Ferry, near WHITE’S
FERRY AQUA CLUB, a commercially operated recreational and campsite
area along the C & O CANAL, on Md. 107, 30 miles northwest of Wash-
ington, D. C. and near THE ARABIAN HORSE FARM at Barnesville.

Maryland’s historic gristmills. U.S. 1, to Kingsville then east on Jericho
Road.

35 ARMY ORDNANCE MUSEUM, Aberdeen Proving Grounds, present-
ing the world’s largest collection of mobile and armored war weapons,
indoor display temporarily closed, off U.S. 40.

36 coNowiInGOo DAM, controlling the Susquehanna River, provides

fine fishing in either the lake; or.the river below the dam, on U.S. 1.

37 BALTIMORE attractions are FORT McHENRY NATIONAL SHRINE,
where the Star-Spangled Banner flew and inspired Francis Scott Key to
compose our national anthem, the FLAG HOUSE MUSEUM, the SHOT
TOWER, the CHARLES CARROLL of CARROLLTON HOUSE, BABE
RUTH HOUSE, BALTIMORE AND OHIO TRANSPORTATION MUSEUM,
the PEALE MUSEUM (America’s first museum), the BALTIMORE MU-
SEUM OF ART, the WALTERS ART GALLERY, JOHNS HOPKINS HOS-
PITAL and UNIVERSITY, the PEABODY INSTITUTE, the EDGAR ALLAN
POE HOUSE, MOUNT CLAIRE MANSION, the ENOCH PRATT FREE
LIBRARY. At the MARYLAND HISTORICAL SOCIETY is the original
manuscript of the ““Star-Spangled Banner,” as well as a vast collection
of Maryland memorabilia, including many War of 1812 and Civil War
relics.

In Baltimore’s immense port area, at Pier 1, Pratt Street, in the heart of
downtown, lies the oldest ship of the United States Navy, the FRIGATE
CONSTELLATION, built in 1797 — now a Registered National Historic

FAIRHILL STEEPLECHASE and flat
turf racing, horse and cattle shows,
spring and fall, on Md. 273 and 280.

61 CHESAPEAKE & DELAWARE

CANAL, Chesapeake City, links Port

of Baltimore with Philadelphia and :
North Atlantic, site of Pump House and Water Wheel (1851). Registered
National Historic Landmark. U.S. 213.

62 OLD BOHEMIA CHURCH, Warwick: the site of the first Catholic
school in the British colonies, on Md. 282, off U.S. 213.

63 FREDERICKTOWN, a picturesque, waterside village with an old
grain warehouse of by-gone days converted into a restaurant near
GEORGETOWN, site of the KITTY KNIGHT HOUSE, now an inn named for
Mistress Kitty, who matched wits with a British admiral and saved the
town in the War of 1812, on U.S. 213.

64 CHESTERTOWN, an old beautiful waterfront community, the site
of Washington College (1782), the only college to which George Wash-
ington personally gave the right to use his name, on U.S. 213.

65 CENTREVILLE, an 18t
century town, with its old
Court House and Lawyer’s



dustry in continuous op-
eration, on Md. 318, near
Preston.

71 oLD TRINITY CHURCH, the oldest Protestant church (1674) in use
in the country, on Md. 16, 5 miles south of Cambridge.

72 BLACKWATER NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, the fall and winter
habitat of one of the nation’s largest concentrations of waterfowl, off Md.
335, 9 miles south of Cambridge. Open daily dawn ’til dusk. Visitor cen-
ter, picnic area, wildlife drive and observation tower.

73 MASON-DIXON MARKER, one of the boundary stones, set 200
years ago by the famous surveyors, Mason and Dixon, to divide Mary-
land from Pennsylvania and Delaware, which established the traditional
line between the North and the South, off U.S. 50 on Md. 467.

74 SALISBURY, the Eastern Shore’s major commercial center, the site
of the NATIONAL INDOOR OPEN TENMIS CHAMPIONSHIP TOURNA-
MENT, on U.S. 50 and 13.

75 OCEAN CITY, one of the finest resorts on the Atlantic Coast, on
ten miles of wide, white sandy beach, with a three-mile boardwalk, all
facilities. and accommodations, and nearby OCEAN DOWNS Harness
Track and FRONTIER TOWN for children. Marlin fishing, off Ocean City
is unexcelled.

Landmark. Also in the port area is McCORMICK COMPANY, world’s

! Row still in use, and
largest spice processor, open for plant tours.

WRIGHT'S CHANCE, an ex-
cellent example of a colonial
Eastern Shore plantation
home, now a museum.

66 wye miLLs, an 18th
century country village with
an old school house, church,
and Maryland’s official tree,
THE WYE OAK (a white
oak), 450 years old, on Md.
404 off U.S. 50.

67 CHESAPEAKE BAY
MARITIME MUSEUM, St.
Michael’s, presents an array
of Bay relics and memora-
bilia, including several old
sailing craft, a lighthouse
and lightship, on Md. 33 off
U.S. 50. (Closed Monday)

68 EASTON, a charming
18th century town, once the
capital of the Eastern Shore,
site of the THIRD HAVEN

76 ASSATEAGUE ISLAND, wildly beautiful barrier reef, the home of
the famous CHINCOTEAGUE ponies, the site of national and state parks
developed for campers, sport fishermen and nature lovers.

77 SNOW HILL, the site of the NASSAWANGO IRON FURNACE ruins,
and the JULIA PURNELL MUSEUM with its unusual collection of historic
memorabilia, on U.S. 113.

78 PRINCESS ANNE, an 18th century town retaining much of its
original charm where in mid-October, “Olde Princess Anne Days” festival
is centered at the TEACKLE MANSION, on U.S. 13.

79 DEAL ISLAND, typical of many Chesapeake Bay fishing villages, on
Md. 363, off U.S. 13.

80 CRISFIELD, a leading Eastern Shore seafood center, port for the
Smith Island excursion boats, on Md. 413, off U.S. 13.

81 SMITH ISLAND, ten miles off shore, in Tangier Sound, a fishing
village virtually unchanged since its settling 300 years ago. Visited by
excursion boats from Crisfield in spring and summer.

82 REHOBETH PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH, the first Presbyterian
church in America (1705), on Md. 667, off U.S. 13.

83 POCOMOKE CITY, on the tropical-like Pocomoke River, noted for
its annual NATIONAL BASS ROUND-UP, on U.S. 13. :

Maryland law requires the operator of a vehicle involved in an
accident to stop immediately and remain at the scene of the accident
until the following requirements have been fulfilled:

1) Render assistance to any person injured.

2) Give his name, address and registration number of the vehicle
he is driving and shall upon request exhibit his operator’s or
chauffeur’s license to the person struck or the person attending
any vehicles involved in the collision.

REPORTING ACCIDENTS

The operator of every motor vehicle which is in any manner involved
In an accident within the state in which any person is killed or
injured, or in which damage to the property of any person including
himself, in excess of $100.00 is sustained, shall within 15 days re-
port the matter in writing to the DEPARTMENT OF MOTOR VEHICLES,
6601 RITCHIE HIGHWAY, N.E, GLEN BURNIE, MARYLAND 21061
Accident report forms may be obtained from the Department of
Motor Vehicles, State and Local Police Department.
